qas.question: Which Alaskan way of transport is more for sport than for transportation?

qas.question: Why were sled-dogs used to deliver medicine to Nome in 1925?

qas.question: Which dogsled race most accurately follows the route of the 1925 serum run?

plausible_answers.text: the famous 1925 serum run to Nome

qas.question: What doesn't the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race commemorate in Alaskan history?
Why were sled-dogs used to deliver medicine to Nome in 1952?

context: Another Alaskan transportation method is the <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>dogsled<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>. In modern times (that is, any time after the mid-late 1920s), dog mushing is more of a sport than a true means of transportation. Various races are held around the state, but the best known is the <a1_0><b7_0>Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race<b7_0/><a1_0/>, a 1,150-mile (1,850 km) trail from Anchorage to Nome (although the distance varies from year to year, the official distance is set at 1,049 miles or 1,688 km). The race commemorates <a2_0><b8_0>the famous 1925 serum run to Nome<b8_0/><a2_0/> in which mushers and dogs like Togo and Balto took much-needed medicine to the diphtheria-stricken community of Nome when <a3_0>all other means of transportation had failed<a3_0/>. Mushers from all over the world come to Anchorage each March to compete for cash, prizes, and prestige. The <a4_0>"<b9_0>Serum Run<b9_0/>"<a4_0/> is another sled dog race that more accurately follows the route of the famous 1925 relay, leaving from the community of Nenana (southwest of Fairbanks) to Nome.
